noun.description: A person's face or facial expression.
examples: his impenetrable eyes and inscrutable countenance give little away
she was giving her specific countenance to the occasion
he was reluctant to countenance the use of force

phrases: Party leaders, however, apparently kept their countenance to avoid getting involved in any issues related to party reform.[, waiting to see what President Chen wanted, Hong said.]
Dislike welled up inside me, but I managed to keep my countenance and voice cordial.
Rachel could continue to sense his scrutiny, and because of that kept her countenance strictly controlled.
For my part I decided that for once in my life it was wisest to keep my countenance.
to keep herself in countenance she opened her notebook
origin: Middle English: from Old French contenance bearing, behavior, from contenir (see contain). The early sense was bearing, demeanor, also facial expression, hence the face.
